units.name: Traditional Tales: Myths from Around the World
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4): increasing their familiarity with a wide range of books, including fairy stories, myths and legends
Writing - Composition (Y3-4): composing and rehearsing sentences orally, including dialogue
text_features_to_teach: archetypal characters (hero, trickster, wise old figure)
units.writing_outcome: Retell a myth from a different culture (400-500 words) preserving key features of the genre including supernatural elements, a quest, and a moral
grammar_focus: multi-clause sentences with conjunctions (when, because, although)

suggested_texts.title: Tales of Ancient Egypt
suggested_texts.author: Roger Lancelyn Green
suggested_texts.note: Accessible retellings with strong narrative structure

suggested_texts.title: The Orchard Book of Greek Myths
suggested_texts.author: Geraldine McCaughrean
suggested_texts.note: Rich vocabulary with clear storytelling

units.pedagogical_rationale: Myths from diverse cultures introduce Y3 to the wider world of traditional storytelling beyond European fairy tales. The common structures across cultures (hero's journey, origin explanations, moral teachings) develop pupils' ability to identify themes and conventions. The retelling task teaches narrative composition within a scaffolded framework — pupils know the story and can focus on language and style.
common_pitfalls: All myths treated as interchangeable rather than exploring how cultural context shapes the story
Retelling is flat plot summary without vivid language or dialogue
Supernatural elements treated superficially rather than exploring why myths use them
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] Ancient civilisations — myths as windows into beliefs and values
[Geography] Where in the world do these myths come from?
[Art] Mythological illustration styles from different cultures

units.name: Report Writing: Non-Chronological Reports
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4): retrieve and record information from non-fiction
Writing - Composition (Y3-4): using organisational devices (headings and sub-headings)
units.writing_outcome: Write a non-chronological report (300-500 words) about a curriculum topic with subheadings, topic sentences, technical vocabulary, and a labelled diagram

suggested_texts.title: DK Eyewitness: Rocks and Minerals
suggested_texts.author: DK
suggested_texts.note: Clear non-fiction layout for modelling report structure

suggested_texts.title: National Geographic Kids: Everything Rocks and Minerals
suggested_texts.author: Steve Tomecek
suggested_texts.note: Accessible layout with subheadings and technical vocabulary

units.pedagogical_rationale: Non-chronological reports are the gateway to academic writing. At Y3, the focus is on organising information under subheadings and using topic sentences — skills that transfer to every subject. Cross-curricular links (Science rocks, Geography rivers) provide authentic content so that the English lesson teaches the writing form while another subject provides the knowledge.
common_pitfalls: Information copied from source without being reorganised or put in own words
Subheadings added but content under each heading is not grouped logically
Formal register drops into chatty, informal language mid-paragraph
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Rocks and soils, plants, animals — any topic with factual content to organise
[Geography] Rivers, weather, local area study

units.name: Adventure Narrative: The BFG
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y3-4): composing sentences using a wider range of structures
Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4): drawing inferences such as inferring characters' feelings, thoughts and motives from their actions
text_features_to_teach: character description through action and dialogue
setting description using expanded noun phrases
units.writing_outcome: Write an adventure narrative chapter (400-500 words) with a character who enters a strange or magical world, using direct speech, expanded noun phrases, and a clear narrative structure

suggested_texts.title: The BFG
suggested_texts.author: Roald Dahl
suggested_texts.note: Rich vocabulary, clear narrative structure, and accessible adventure plot

suggested_texts.title: The Hodgeheg
suggested_texts.author: Dick King-Smith
suggested_texts.note: Shorter alternative with adventure elements and humour

units.pedagogical_rationale: The BFG provides an ideal model for Y3 adventure narrative because its portal-fantasy structure (child enters a strange world) is a clear, replicable pattern. Dahl's distinctive voice and inventive vocabulary inspire children's own language choices. The text naturally demands direct speech punctuation (the conversations between Sophie and the BFG) making grammar teaching contextual rather than decontextualised.
common_pitfalls: Direct speech punctuation taught in isolation then not transferred to independent narrative writing
Character description is a static list of adjectives rather than revealed through action and dialogue
Adventure plot is all action with no reflective or descriptive moments
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Dreams and sleep — the BFG's dream-catching links to understanding sleep
[PSHE] Friendship, bravery, and standing up for what is right

units.name: Poetry: Shape Poems and Calligrams
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4): recognising some different forms of poetry
Writing - Composition (Y3-4): composing and rehearsing sentences orally
text_features_to_teach: visual layout as part of meaning (shape poems)
units.writing_outcome: Write at least 2 poems: one shape poem where the layout reflects the subject, and one using similes, then perform one to an audience with expression
units.spoken_language_outcome: Perform a poem to the class with expression, gesture, and eye contact

suggested_texts.title: The Works: Poems for Key Stage 2
suggested_texts.author: Pie Corbett (ed.)
suggested_texts.note: Wide range of forms including shape poems and calligrams

suggested_texts.title: Falling Out of the Sky
suggested_texts.author: Rachel Rooney
suggested_texts.note: Inventive forms with strong imagery

units.pedagogical_rationale: Shape poems and calligrams make the connection between form and meaning visible and concrete. At Y3, this is an accessible way to teach that poetic form is a deliberate choice that shapes how the reader experiences the poem. Similes are introduced as the first explicit figurative language device because 'like' and 'as' provide clear signals that make the device identifiable.
common_pitfalls: Shape poems become about drawing the shape rather than crafting the language
Similes are formulaic ('as big as a house') rather than original and precise
Performance is rushed through without attention to pace, volume, and expression
cross_curricular_hooks: [Art] Visual poetry as art — creating illustrated calligrams
[Science] Shape poems about natural phenomena (water, fire, animals)

units.name: Adventure Narrative: The Iron Man
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y3-4)
Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4)
English Appendix 2 (Y4 grammar)
text_features_to_teach: vivid description using expanded noun phrases
units.writing_outcome: Write an adventure narrative (500-700 words) with clear problem-resolution structure, vivid description using expanded noun phrases, and dialogue punctuated with inverted commas

suggested_texts.title: The Iron Man
suggested_texts.author: Ted Hughes
suggested_texts.note: Clear three-act structure, rich vocabulary, accessible themes of fear and friendship

suggested_texts.title: Stig of the Dump
suggested_texts.author: Clive King
suggested_texts.note: Alternative anchor text with adventure and historical elements

units.pedagogical_rationale: Ted Hughes' The Iron Man provides a rich model for adventure narrative writing with its clear problem-resolution structure, vivid descriptive language, and dialogue that advances the plot. The text's accessible yet ambitious vocabulary and structural clarity make it an ideal mentor text for Y4 pupils learning to sustain narrative writing across multiple paragraphs with fronted adverbials and expanded noun phrases.
common_pitfalls: Pupils retell The Iron Man rather than writing their own adventure narrative using its structural features
Dialogue added decoratively rather than used to advance the plot or reveal character
Fronted adverbials used repetitively without varying sentence openings
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Materials and their properties — the Iron Man's metal body
[PSHE] Themes of fear, friendship, and acceptance of difference
[Art] Illustration and character design inspired by the text

units.name: Myths and Legends: Greek Myths
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4): increasing familiarity with fairy stories, myths and legends
Writing - Composition (Y3-4): composing and rehearsing sentences orally
units.writing_outcome: Retell a Greek myth in own words (400-600 words) preserving key features and adding vivid description

suggested_texts.title: Greek Myths
suggested_texts.author: Marcia Williams
suggested_texts.note: Accessible comic-strip style retellings

suggested_texts.title: Atticus the Storyteller
suggested_texts.author: Lucy Coats
suggested_texts.note: Rich narrative retellings of 100 Greek myths

suggested_texts.title: Who Let the Gods Out?
suggested_texts.author: Maz Evans
suggested_texts.note: Modern novel with Greek mythology context

units.pedagogical_rationale: Greek myths offer an ideal vehicle for exploring narrative conventions, themes, and character archetypes at Y4 level. The recurring structures across different myths (heroic quest, supernatural elements, moral lessons) allow pupils to identify common features and practise retelling with their own embellishments, developing both comprehension and compositional skills.
common_pitfalls: Pupils confuse myths with fairy tales or legends, losing the distinctive features of each genre
Retelling becomes a copy rather than a genuine reimagining with the pupil's own descriptive voice
Cross-referencing themes across myths is superficial without explicit modelling of how to compare
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] Ancient Greece topic — myths as primary sources for understanding beliefs and values
[Art] Greek pottery and mythological illustration
[Drama] Dramatic retelling and performance of myths

units.name: Persuasive Writing: Save Our Park
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y3-4)
Writing - Vocabulary, Grammar and Punctuation (Y3-4)
units.writing_outcome: Write a persuasive letter (300-500 words) using formal structure, rhetorical devices, and paragraphed arguments
grammar_focus: paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme

suggested_texts.title: Model persuasive letters (teacher-curated)
suggested_texts.author: Various
suggested_texts.note: Teacher models with clear persuasive features annotated

suggested_texts.title: Newspaper opinion columns (adapted)
suggested_texts.author: Various
suggested_texts.note: Age-appropriate editorials for analysing persuasive technique

units.pedagogical_rationale: Persuasive writing develops pupils' ability to organise ideas logically, consider audience, and use language for deliberate effect. The 'Save Our Park' scenario provides a purposeful, real-world context that motivates genuine persuasion rather than formulaic letter-writing. It also bridges reading (identifying persuasive techniques in model texts) with writing (deploying those techniques independently).
common_pitfalls: Pupils list opinions without supporting them with evidence or reasoning
Rhetorical questions used excessively rather than strategically for effect
Formal register lapses into informal language without the pupil noticing the shift
cross_curricular_hooks: [Geography] Local area study and land use
[PSHE] Community participation and civic responsibility
[Maths] Data collection and presentation to support arguments

units.name: Poetry: Performance and Form
units.subject: English

Writing - Composition (Y3-4)
Spoken Language: use spoken language to develop understanding
units.writing_outcome: Write poems in at least 2 different forms and perform one to an audience with appropriate expression, pace, and volume
units.spoken_language_outcome: Perform a poem to an audience with appropriate expression, pace, and volume

suggested_texts.title: The Works: Every Kind of Poem
suggested_texts.author: Paul Cookson (ed.)
suggested_texts.note: Comprehensive anthology with haiku, limerick, free verse, narrative poetry

suggested_texts.title: Quick Let's Get Out of Here
suggested_texts.author: Michael Rosen
suggested_texts.note: Performance-ready poems with strong voice and humour

suggested_texts.title: Revolting Rhymes
suggested_texts.author: Roald Dahl
suggested_texts.note: Narrative poetry that subverts fairy tale conventions

units.pedagogical_rationale: Poetry study at Y4 develops pupils' appreciation of language precision and sound. Exploring multiple forms (haiku, limerick, free verse, narrative poetry) builds understanding that form shapes meaning and that poets make deliberate structural choices. The performance element is a statutory spoken language requirement and builds fluency, expression, and confidence.
common_pitfalls: Focus on rhyme at the expense of meaning, imagery, and effect
Performance reduced to recitation without attention to expression, pace, or volume
Pupils write only in forms with strict rules (haiku, limerick) and avoid the challenge of free verse
cross_curricular_hooks: [Music] Rhythm and beat in poetry — links to musical metre
[History] Narrative poetry as a way of retelling historical events
[PSHE] Self-expression and confidence through performance

Writing - Composition (Y3-4): using organisational devices

units.pedagogical_rationale: Non-chronological reports develop pupils' ability to organise factual information logically using subheadings, topic sentences, and technical vocabulary. The cross-curricular link to Science or Geography provides authentic content for report writing, ensuring pupils write with genuine knowledge rather than padding. Retrieval and recording skills are also explicitly statutory at Y4.
common_pitfalls: Reports become lists of copied facts rather than synthesised and reorganised information
Subheadings used as decoration rather than as genuine organisational tools for the reader
Technical vocabulary inserted without understanding, leading to inaccurate usage

units.name: Fairy Tales: Rewriting the Classics
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4): increasing familiarity with fairy stories
Writing - Composition (Y3-4): composing and rehearsing sentences orally
units.writing_outcome: Write a fairy tale retelling (500-700 words) with a twist on the traditional version

suggested_texts.title: The True Story of the 3 Little Pigs
suggested_texts.author: Jon Scieszka
suggested_texts.note: Classic retelling from the villain's perspective

suggested_texts.title: Revolting Rhymes
suggested_texts.author: Roald Dahl
suggested_texts.note: Subverted fairy tales in verse form

suggested_texts.title: Traditional tales collection
suggested_texts.author: Various
suggested_texts.note: Original versions for comparison

units.pedagogical_rationale: Comparing traditional fairy tales with modern retellings develops critical reading skills, particularly inference about character motives and thematic understanding. The retelling task scaffolds narrative writing effectively because pupils already know the plot structure and can focus on language choices, perspective shifts, and subverting reader expectations rather than generating plot from scratch.
common_pitfalls: The 'twist' is superficial (changing names only) rather than a genuine subversion of expectations or perspective
Pupils struggle to maintain fairy tale conventions while simultaneously subverting them
Comparison work stays at plot level without exploring how language and perspective create different effects
cross_curricular_hooks: [Drama] Performing fairy tales from different characters' perspectives
[Art] Illustrating traditional versus modern fairy tale scenes for contrast
[PSHE] Exploring themes of good and evil, justice, and morality in fairy tales

units.name: Spelling and Vocabulary: Word Detective
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Spelling (Appendix 1): Y3-4 word list and spelling rules
Reading - Word Reading (Y3-4)
Writing - Transcription (Y3-4)
units.writing_outcome: Spelling log with word families, rules, and corrections applied in extended writing

suggested_texts.author: Various
suggested_texts.note: For investigating word origins and patterns

units.pedagogical_rationale: Systematic spelling instruction at Y4 must go beyond rote memorisation to build morphological awareness through prefixes, suffixes, and root words. An investigative approach where pupils act as 'word detectives' develops etymological curiosity and transferable spelling strategies. This maps directly to the statutory Y3-4 word list and Appendix 1 spelling rules.
common_pitfalls: Spelling taught in isolation from reading and writing contexts, reducing transfer to independent work
Over-reliance on 'look, cover, write, check' without understanding the morphological rule behind the spelling
Homophones practised as pairs but not embedded in sentence-level context where the distinction matters
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] Etymology and word origins — Latin and Greek roots in English
[Languages] Comparing English spelling patterns with French and Spanish cognates
[Science] Technical vocabulary with Latin and Greek roots

Writing - Composition (Y3-4)
Reading - Comprehension (Y3-4)
units.writing_outcome: Write a balanced discussion text (400-600 words) presenting both sides of the argument with a justified conclusion
units.spoken_language_outcome: Participate in a structured class debate, presenting arguments for and against with evidence
grammar_focus: conjunctions, adverbs and prepositions for time and cause
paragraphs to organise ideas around a theme

suggested_texts.author: Tony Stead

units.pedagogical_rationale: Structured debate develops both oracy and writing simultaneously, which the NC requires at Y4. The zoo question provides a genuine moral dilemma with accessible arguments on both sides, making it easier for pupils to construct balanced arguments. Moving from spoken discussion to written balanced argument teaches pupils that writing captures and refines oral reasoning.
common_pitfalls: Discussion dominated by a few confident speakers while quieter pupils disengage
Written arguments present personal opinion as the only valid position rather than genuinely balancing both sides
Connectives for contrast (however, on the other hand) used mechanically as sentence starters without genuine argumentative purpose
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Animal habitats, adaptation, and conservation
[Geography] Endangered species and human impact on environments
[PSHE] Ethical decision-making and respecting different viewpoints

units.name: Narrative: Myth-Inspired Fiction
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y5-6): selecting appropriate grammar and vocabulary, understanding how such choices can change and enhance meaning
Reading - Comprehension (Y5-6): maintaining positive attitudes to reading and understanding of what they read
text_features_to_teach: character development through dialogue and action
units.writing_outcome: Write a myth-inspired narrative (600-800 words) with controlled narrative voice, atmospheric description using figurative language, and a clear thematic arc
grammar_focus: modal verbs for possibility and obligation

suggested_texts.title: Beowulf

suggested_texts.note: Morpurgo's accessible retelling with rich descriptive language

suggested_texts.author: Terry Jones
suggested_texts.note: Humorous mythological adventure with Norse setting

units.pedagogical_rationale: At Y5, narrative writing moves from retelling to original composition with conscious stylistic choices. Myth-inspired fiction provides a bridge: pupils draw on the structural patterns of myth (quest, challenge, transformation) while developing their own narrative voice and descriptive style. This unit introduces relative clauses and parenthesis as tools for adding detail and complexity to sentences.
common_pitfalls: Story is all plot with no atmospheric description or character development
Figurative language used randomly rather than to create a consistent atmosphere
Relative clauses and parenthetical asides interrupt flow rather than enhancing it
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] Anglo-Saxon and Viking Britain — myths as cultural artefacts
[Art] Illustration of mythological scenes using atmospheric techniques

units.name: Persuasion and Discussion: Balanced Argument
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Writing - Composition (Y5-6): identifying the audience for and purpose of the writing
Writing - Composition (Y5-6): using further organisational and presentational devices
units.writing_outcome: Write an extended balanced argument (500-700 words) on a topical issue with evidence from multiple sources, formal register, and a nuanced conclusion

suggested_texts.title: Model discussion texts (teacher-curated)
suggested_texts.author: Various
suggested_texts.note: Exemplars with annotated cohesive devices and hedging language

suggested_texts.title: First News / The Week Junior articles
suggested_texts.author: Various
suggested_texts.note: Age-appropriate news articles presenting multiple viewpoints

units.spoken_language_outcome: Lead or participate in a structured formal debate, summarising key arguments from both sides
units.pedagogical_rationale: At Y5, discussion writing becomes more analytically demanding. Pupils must move beyond simple for/against to acknowledge complexity, use hedging language (may, could, tends to), and build cohesion across paragraphs. The formal debate component develops the spoken language competence needed for secondary school. Modal verbs and passive voice are statutory Y5 grammar and fit naturally into academic register.
common_pitfalls: Arguments are still binary (for/against) without acknowledging nuance or complexity
Modal verbs and passive voice used because the teacher says so, not because the register demands them
Conclusion simply repeats the strongest argument rather than genuinely weighing the evidence
cross_curricular_hooks: [PSHE] Current affairs and ethical issues
[Science] Environmental issues (deforestation, plastic, climate change)
[Geography] Global issues with local impact

units.pedagogical_rationale: At Y5, poetry study introduces comparison across time periods and styles — a skill directly required for KS3 and GCSE. Comparing a classic poem with a contemporary response develops critical awareness that poetry exists in dialogue across time. The writing task (responding to a classic poem) gives pupils a scaffold while demanding original expression.
common_pitfalls: Comparison stays at surface level (one is old, one is new) without analysing how language and form create different effects
Pupils' own poems imitate the classic too closely rather than responding with their own voice
Performance is flat and rushed — insufficient rehearsal time allocated

dialogue revealing character and advancing plot

active and passive voice for effect

units.pedagogical_rationale: Y6 narrative is the culmination of primary English writing. Pupils must demonstrate 'conscious grammatical control' (NC) and the ability to select vocabulary and grammar to 'change and enhance meaning.' This unit bridges to KS3 by introducing literary fiction concepts (narrative voice, symbolism, structural choices) that will be central to secondary English study. The longer piece (700-1000 words) develops writing stamina needed for KS3.
common_pitfalls: Narrative voice is inconsistent — slipping between first and third person or between formal and informal
Advanced punctuation (semi-colons, colons) used incorrectly or forced into the writing
Structural choices (flashback, multiple perspectives) attempted but executed confusingly
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] Historical fiction drawing on KS2 history topics
[PSHE] Themes of identity, growing up, and moral choice

units.subject: English

Writing - Vocabulary, Grammar and Punctuation (Y5-6): using the passive voice, formal vocabulary
text_features_to_teach: subjunctive mood (if I were, were he to)
cohesive devices across an extended piece

units.spoken_language_outcome: Deliver a formal presentation on a topical issue to the class, using Standard English and structured argument
units.pedagogical_rationale: Y6 formal writing is the direct bridge to KS3 academic writing. The NC requires subjunctive forms and passive voice to be taught at Y6, and both are best introduced in the context of formal essay writing where they serve a genuine purpose (objectivity, formality). This unit ensures pupils arrive at secondary school able to write in a controlled formal register — a skill many KS3 teachers identify as the biggest gap.
common_pitfalls: Passive voice and subjunctive inserted artificially rather than used where the register demands them
Formal register collapses into informal language in the middle of the piece
Arguments are opinions dressed up in formal language rather than genuine evidence-based reasoning
cross_curricular_hooks: [PSHE] Topical ethical issues (environment, technology, rights)
[Science] Scientific debates (space exploration, genetic modification)

units.name: Shakespeare: A Midsummer Night's Dream
units.subject: English
curriculum_reference: Reading - Comprehension (Y5-6): increasing their familiarity with a wide range of books, including from our literary heritage
Spoken Language: participate in discussions, presentations, performances, role play, improvisations and debates
units.writing_outcome: Write a modern retelling of one scene from A Midsummer Night's Dream (400-600 words) or a character diary entry exploring a character's motives and feelings
units.spoken_language_outcome: Perform a scene from the play with expression, movement, and audience awareness
grammar_focus: direct speech punctuation in playscript format

suggested_texts.title: A Midsummer Night's Dream (Usborne Illustrated)

suggested_texts.note: Accessible illustrated adaptation with original language extracts

suggested_texts.title: A Midsummer Night's Dream (Shakespeare Stories)
suggested_texts.author: Andrew Matthews / Tony Ross
suggested_texts.note: Narrative retelling that preserves key language and plot

units.pedagogical_rationale: While Shakespeare is not statutory until KS3, the vast majority of primary schools introduce Shakespeare in Y6 as preparation for secondary school. A Midsummer Night's Dream is the most popular choice because its comedy, magic, and mistaken identity are accessible to 10-11 year olds. The performance element develops spoken language skills and confidence. Encountering Shakespearean language at Y6 reduces the anxiety of meeting it at KS3.
common_pitfalls: Too much time spent on plot comprehension, too little on language exploration and performance
Shakespearean language presented as incomprehensible rather than as a puzzle to be decoded
Writing task defaults to plot summary rather than creative response or analytical diary entry
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] Tudor and Jacobean theatre — the Globe, Elizabethan audience
[Drama] Performance techniques and stagecraft
[Art] Set and costume design for a production
